unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate effective use of theories of power to analyse the impact of politics on Indigenous Australians.
Critically analyse the political positions of historical and contemporary texts.
Examine the implications that colonialism has had on Indigenous Australiansâ€™ rights and access to education.
Confidently use online communication forums and engage in informed interactive learning.
Demonstrated high level of written communication skills including structuring and supporting an academic argument.
Explain how government policy and legislation has and continues to impact Indigenous Australians socially, economically, and politically.

assessments.description: The Quiz is based on unit content and will be available online
This task requires students to choose one question from a list provided. The essay will ask students to critically engage with Indigenous research frameworks outlined in the unit.
Students will be required to actively participate in weekly online tutorial activities. These will be available on a weekly basis on iLearn.

data.subject_search_title: INED8030 - Politics, Power and Indigenous Education
data.description: This unit examines the relationship between politics, power and colonialism and education as it relates to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations. By examining a range of government policies and legislation students will gain a more detailed understanding of the social, cultural, economic and political impact on Indigenous people. This unit also focuses on contemporary and historical Indigenous led activism in relation to education.
